svg.text: Modular Local AI Agent / Event-Driven Concurrency / Multi-Interface Control System

g.text: main.py - Core Bootstrap and System Initialization
Environment Loading / Memory Manager Init / Brain Startup
BRAIN CORE MODULE (brain.py) - CENTRAL DECISION ENGINE
SYSTEM LIBRARIES: pyautogui / pycaw / psutil / subprocess / PIL / cv2
Direct Windows API access through Python bindings and low-level process/hardware control
Enables system-wide automation and hardware interaction capabilities
FEATURE LIBRARIES: os.walk / pathlib / clipboard-api / watchdog
File indexing with caching and intelligent searching capabilities
Event-driven monitoring for file system changes and activity logging
BACKGROUND PROCESS THREADS - CONCURRENT SYSTEM MONITORS
LAYER 5: OS AND HARDWARE INTERACTION LAYER
OPERATING SYSTEM AND HARDWARE ABSTRACTION LAYER
wake_word.py detects activation phrase -> voice.py captures speech input -> brain.py processes intent (system_command)
dispatcher routes to system agent -> OS control module executes shutdown via PowerShell -> OS kernel processes termination
CRITICAL PATH: Interface Input -> Controller Processing -> Agent Execution -> OS Output -> Hardware Action
Latency Profile: Voice Capture (100ms) -> Intent Detection (50ms) -> Tool Selection (20ms) -> System Execution (500ms)
FLOW 2: Telegram Remote File Search Request
Telegram user sends search command -> telegram.py parses request -> brain.py determines intent (file_search)
dispatcher calls file finder feature -> file finder searches local index with fuzzy matching -> results formatted -> sent via Telegram API
CRITICAL PATH: Remote Input -> Message Parse -> Brain Route -> Feature Execution -> Response Format -> Remote Output
Latency Profile: API Polling (1s) -> Command Parse (20ms) -> Brain Processing (100ms) -> Search Execution (200ms) -> API Response (100ms)
FLOW 3: Browser Tab Monitoring with Context Awareness
Browser extension captures tab change -> HTTP listener receives event in background thread -> activity monitor logs window/URL pair
memory logger saves context with timestamp -> user asks about browser history -> brain retrieves from memory module -> data returned
CRITICAL PATH: Extension Event -> Background Monitor -> Memory Store -> Query Processing -> Data Retrieval -> Context Response
Latency Profile: Extension Event (10ms) -> Background Handler (5ms) -> Memory Storage (20ms) -> Query Processing (30ms) -> Response (10ms)

svg.text: Zyron Assistant implements a rigorous layered architecture with strict separation of concerns. The Interface Layer receives input from
multiple sources (voice, Telegram, browser extensions). These inputs converge on the Brain Controller Layer, which uses sophisticated
inference engine capabilities including intent detection, tool selection, and response generation. The Memory Manager maintains conversational
context and historical data for stateful interactions.
The Agent Execution Layer contains specialized controllers for system operations and feature implementations. System Agent handles OS-level
control (shutdown, restart, media control, input simulation, hardware access). Features Agent manages data intelligence (activity monitoring,
clipboard history, file searching, file tracking).
Concurrent Background Monitors run continuously in separate threads, enabling passive monitoring without blocking main execution. These include
wake word detection, Telegram polling, clipboard monitoring, activity tracking, file system events, browser tab monitoring, context persistence,
and optional camera capture. The OS/Hardware Abstraction Layer provides standardized access to system resources through well-established Python
libraries. All computation occurs locally using Ollama for language model inference, ensuring privacy and offline operation. Telegram acts purely
as a remote command interface adapter without accessing sensitive data.
